reviews.review_msg: Amazing professor! I learned so much—not just the course material, but also how to think critically and apply theory to real-world situations. The teaching style made a huge difference, and I truly appreciate everything I gained from this course! Highly recommend!

Genuinely worst professor I have ever had at SFU, and I have been going here for four years. I strongly recommend anyone considering this class to not take it. The entire course is writing, two papers and two exams that are only long answer.

She constantly brings up her personal vendetta against feminist scholars for "taking grant money from her".
Really interesting course with engaging content! The TA was tough and had high expectations. But in the end, I got a good grade, so it was worth the effort!

I've had Dr. Lysova in the past and decided to take her class again. This time around... the grading was way more challenging, exams had an unnecessary amount of writing for a non-W course, and the TA had poorly structured tutorials where we were all fighting to talk for participation because the TA took up most of the time to give redundant PPTs.
Prof is fine, TA needs to reconsider her career path. I've never had such a bad TA in my 5 years at SFU

Honestly I was scared looking at the reviews but class was not bad. Had Janine as my TA, absolute best. She always clarified and provided amazing feedback. Prof's lectures were interesting/informational. End of term test was kind of surprising and difficult - the theories tested were not common theories. Midterm paper 8-10 pages + final paper 12-15
Grading made zero sense this semester. unclear guidelines and not a single person getting full marks in tutorials lol.
This course was super interesting, and I especially loved the video materials—they made everything so much easier to understand. Recommend.

Had Lysova in the spring where it was easy to get an A, assumed it would be the same. She stated at the beginning of the semester she marked too easily in spring and has now taken it out on this semester's students. Discussion worth way too much for the 10 mins we r given in tutorial to discuss. Where it ends up being 17 students fighting to talk.
Great course and an excellent professor! I learned a lot, though there was more writing than I expected.
Good prof, but inexperienced and strict TA.

This needs to be considered a W course. Expecting us to write 12 pgs for the midterm and final exam is absurd. Don't get me started on the TA. I don't even think she even knew what she wanted from us. 20% for tutorial participation is ridiculous. If I EVER get this TA again I am going to DROP OUT OF THE COURSE.
Don't take this class unless you really have to. Not as interesting as it could be, not a GPA booster, and the TA is insufferable
great class if you like crying during a final

I didn't learn anything in this class that I didn't already know. Lectures were hard to follow bc she went off track often. The ta seemed nice at first but ended up grading everything very harshly and was not helpful at all when it came to questions about course content and assignments. Lysova and the ta are both hard to reach outside of class.
u could do good in the whole class and here comes the final to knock u down
Brutal final
Dr. Lysova if you're reading this, please get a better TA ):

The TA made the class unbearable. Participation is worth a lot and instead of allowing students to have enough discussion time to earn their marks, she opted for teaching 4th yr students how to write a basic thesis statement/essay. Lectures were also boring. Their grading is brutal too, it seems like they take pride in their students doing poorly.
you guys…what was that final exam…i'm so mind bLOWN at how atrocious it is omg… we better be CURVED

didn't go to a single lecture, put in minimal effort and got a B+. Very easy class, just grind out a couple papers on the day its due and u can forget about this class for the rest of the semester. other than tutorial participation which was whatever

This is the worst crim class I have ever taken at SFU. Steer clear of Dr. Lysova and her power-tripping TA. 20% of your grade comes from tutorial participation which is impossible to get full marks in, and no they will not articulate how you can get a better grade. They are hard markers who don't seem to actually want their students to succeed. Bad

TA graded like a warzone. no time to speak in tutorials, boring lectures where she is just throwing information endlessly at you, and then tutorials had no time to speak and even when you speak as much as possible, you still do not get full marks. not a single person got full marks in 80% of the tutorials... I do not know what she is doing recently

Dr. Lysova's class was a breath of fresh air. I found applying theories to real-life scenarios incredibly engaging. Dr. Lysova's encouragement of critical thinking and objectivity made her an exceptional instructor.
Professor Lysova's lectures provide insight into contemporary issues relating to social behaviours and criminality. Highly recommended!

Prof is very well educated and kind. TA makes ur grade, and Marjan was very nice but soooo slow in marking. But, I am happy with my mark in the end because both were accessible and easy to communicate with.

Dr. Lysova's course completely changed my perspective. Applying theories to everyday situations felt so natural by the end. I'm grateful for Dr. Lysova's emphasis on critical thinking; it was truly valuable. Her teaching style, which was both objective and creative, made her stand out as an excellent professor.

Nice prof but there are major areas where she can improve:

1. Communicate with TAs better because it leads to miscommunication and it was present during the course.

2. A final exam where we're given 2 hours to write 3 essays (6 pages each) being graded on grammar, isn't too realistic.

3. Be present since during the final exam, she wasn't there.
The best professor at SFU. Dr. Lysova is highly educated, knowledgeable, passionate, and kind. Also, she did her best to support us during the strike.

She is a great professor and does an excellent job explaining different points of view. I appreciate the integration of theory in each type of violence. Discussions were the most useful. Very understanding of the students' needs.

Prof was difficult during the strike, refused to move classes online. The tutorial questions were long and required lots of research. The test questions were given a week before the exams and was hard to study for with other finals/classes going on. Tutorial participation was a heavy part of grade, despite only having a few, due to strikes/holiday
Be wary of  power hungry T.A.'s taking charge over entire course despite their absences

very passionate about what she teaches and it shows. could have been more accommodating with the TA strike, would be nice to have lectures online instead of making us go with no tutorials. gives the test questions a WEEK before the test and you just need to prep, many students complained but they clearly didn't study cause it was super easy.

I enjoyed this class. Although lectures were not mandatory, they were informative and helped understand difficult concepts. Case studies and examples were interesting and helpful. Tutorial participation mattered.

Lectures were pretty useless for this course since the two papers you have to write were just based on the textbook, however, attendance for tutorials was mandatory since it's worth a significant portion of your grade. Overall, the course itself was not difficult but the papers did feel repetitive as they were pretty much about the same topic.

No exams which made lectures very optional (went to first 2 and that was it). You have to write 2 papers and submit outlines a couple weeks before the real thing is due. They're long ones (10-15 pages each) but the topics are relatively easy to write a lot about. Tutorial participation is worth like 25% so its important u show up and participate.

You really don't need to go to the boring lectures because assignments can be done with the readings only. Assignments are not too hard if you listen exactly to what they are asking and they give clear instructions. For tutorial make sure you show up, raise questions, and engage in the material to deepen the discussion and you'll get marked fairly

Lectures were boring and not needed to do well in the class since you were only graded on papers. Participation in tutorial was worth 30% and you have to basically answer every discussion question to get full marks. The papers had clear grading criteria but were required to be much longer than what should have been necessary to explain your point.

Dr. Lysova is hands down the best prof in SFU crim. Her classes are so wonderful and her guidelines for papers are like i've never seen before. She lays out EXACTLY what you need to do, and tbh if someone got a bad mark on the paper its probably because they tried to cut corners on what was asked in the criteria. 10/10 prof i recommend her always!

Super interesting course and you learn a lot. Discussions were a lot of fun and everyone had plenty of opportunities to contribute. We could choose a topic for the term paper, which was also helpful and reflected our interests.

There were only 2 assignments: a midterm and final paper, 8 and 12 pages respectively. Participation in tutorials was kinda bad because you had to read some random research study and talk about it for tutorial on top of the textbook and it was worth a lot. My TA wasn't clear on the rubric and lots of people ended up really low in a grade worth 30%

Dr. Lysova was a great prof to teach this course. However, the lectures were rushed and the seminars were based on 100+ pg readings. Other students got bad grade on participation but contrib equally. Exam and term paper was straightforward. Just read and study, state your opinions/examples too. Not taking 300W with her bc of course grading

Her 300W course isn't as bad as 313, because you're not expected to read hundreds of pages of some geriatric boomer's opinions. Also, the lectures are relevant and while not necessary to attend, can at least help you understand the course content better. Also, Kayleigh was helpful and accessible outside of class. Definitely a tough grader though.

Each seminar is rated on a 1-5 scale for participation, which makes up 25% of your overall grade. The main issues I have are that the readings are literally over 80+ pages of dry content a week, and the lectures are irrelevant, yet you have to attend for the sake of participation. Also, the midterm is 2 in-class six page essays. Wouldn't recommend.

It was a very interesting class and I learned a lot! This course has provided a lot of insight into the different perspectives of family violence that aren't always discussed in the mainstream media or research. Thank you, Professor Lysova
This class went smoothly online and I enjoyed all of the content during this course. Lots of feedback on the drafts was helpful and made me feel more comfortable with writing.

The papers for this class are unnecessarily difficult. You are required to write 15 pages for the final paper with a whopping 21 required sources cited, 15 of which must be academic journal articles. The due date for the good copy is rendered void by the draft (completed in full) which is due 3 weeks prior. Class was basically taught by the TA.

I'm currently sitting at a B- going into the final. This course is one of the more difficult criminology courses, but with the right prof you can get the grade you desire. I felt she was a very tough grader for papers. I have taken Alexandra Lysova before, and she is much better in person. The course really hasn't adapted to online.

Dr. Lysova is one of my favourite professors at SFU. Her lectures are engaging and she clearly knows a lot about the area of violence and family violence in particular. Her grading expectations are clear and she is very open to students asking questions.

I took Family Violence and Criminal Justice with Dr. Lysova and it was definitely one of my favourite courses I took during my time at SFU. She's extremely knowledgeable about the course content and great at answering any questions in detail. It's easy to tell how much she genuinely cares for her student. I will miss her lectures!

Dr. Lysova is such a warm and engaging professor, she made a lot of connections to real-life contexts that made an otherwise theoretically dense class interesting and memorable. She is easy to reach via e-mail and is understanding and approachable, I can't recommend her enough. The final is quite intimidating, however, so do be prepared for that.

Amazing semester and great class! I have enjoyed this course thoroughly and have learned many things about family violence. Dr. Lysova is an amazing professor. I have recommended this course to so many students because the material is important to learn. I have learned so many skills that can be applied to other criminology courses. Thank you!
The final exam expected 3500-4000 words for five long answer essay questions in three hours. Pretty unrealistic and needlessly stressful. Thanks. Okay lecturer but change your course formatting.

Terrible final. 3 hours to write 5 questions didnt sound too terrible until you realized she wanted 3500-4000 words ... other than that this class was great. TAs mark everything, I lucked out with Kayleigh, she was accommodating and easy to understand (unlike mass emails from Ryan) I hope they change expectations for the final in the future
Your exam and paper grades will depend on your TA at least that's how it was last sem. However, it is not a difficult class at all.
Thanks to you people who never went to lecture she does not post lecture slides anymore

Dr. Lysova is an excellent prof. She gives clear guidelines and grades fairly. You must do the readings for this class. All of them. Shes very knowledgeable on family violence and will deduct points if you miss important points or clearly arent sure what youre talking about. Overall, do the work and youll be rewarded
Great teacher, loved attending lectures and always discussed interesting topics. Would definitely take other classes with her.

Barely went to lecture as Dr. Lysova often went on tangents and would go very fast through her slides. However she does post her slides so you can review them on your own. Make sure you follow your TA's expectations as there were different expectations. Final exam was very fair. Save yourself some money and dont buy the textbook.

Alexandra is a good professor. I never went to lecture since she posts all her slides online and managed to be fine. This a W course so get ready to write; however, the papers were marked fairly. Don't buy the textbook you do not really need it (I barely used it this semester). Overall, good professor.
Dr. Lysova is very passionate about the course content and is great at encouraging class discussion. Her knowledge of the subject is impressive! Very friendly. Great Professor!

Alexandra is knowledgeable in her field. Although the class was dry and about theories, she tried to engage students. Her notes were easy to read and she was always encouraged questions from students. Great prof. She is easy to get ahold of and is caring prof outside of the classrooms
Excellent lectures. Really enthusiastic about class content. I really liked it. Also very happy that she expanded the info beyond what the text said. Great professor!
Professor Lysova has a lot of energy and does a great job of keeping us focused and interested in the class. I really enjoyed this class, especially for an 8:30 am one! :)

Alexandra was very knowledgeable and passionate about the course material, which made the learning environment enjoyable. She was always helpful and clarified any questions or concerns. Overall great professor!

It's a mandatory class and she seems to be the only one teaching it recently... seems to love the biological perspectives of crime? Doesn't post slides online and zooms through things that aren't in the textbook and cannot be found anywhere... likes to show movies and video clips, criteria on syllabus completely changed by TA's for assignments >:(

She displays genuine interest in the subject. Her lectures are not the most interesting but they are not boring either. I felt like her class breakdown could have been better. I found she was ambiguous in what she wanted out of our work but really specific in her marking. You will have to work to get a good mark in the course.
